an3.154:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are three kinds of homage.

an3.154:1.3.eng: By way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.154:1.4.eng: These are the three kinds of homage.”

an3.155:1.1.pli: “Ye, bhikkhave, sattā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ kāyena sucaritaṃ caranti, vācāya sucaritaṃ caranti, manasā sucaritaṃ caranti, supubbaṇho, bhikkhave, tesaṃ sattānaṃ.
an3.155:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, those sentient beings who do good things in the morning by way of body, speech, and mind have a good morning.

an3.155:2.1.pli: Ye, bhikkhave, sattā majjhanhikasamayaṃ kāyena sucaritaṃ caranti, vācāya sucaritaṃ caranti, manasā sucaritaṃ caranti, sumajjhanhiko, bhikkhave, tesaṃ sattānaṃ.
an3.155:2.1.eng: Those sentient beings who do good things at midday by way of body, speech, and mind have a good midday.

an3.155:3.1.pli: Ye, bhikkhave, sattā sāyanhasamayaṃ kāyena sucaritaṃ caranti, vācāya sucaritaṃ caranti, manasā sucaritaṃ caranti, susāyanho, bhikkhave, tesaṃ sattānanti.
an3.155:3.1.eng: Those sentient beings who do good things in the evening by way of body, speech, and mind have a good evening.

an3.155:4.1.eng: A good star, a good fortune,

an3.155:4.2.eng: a good dawn, a good rising,

an3.155:4.3.eng: a good moment, a good hour:

an3.155:4.4.eng: these come with good gifts to spiritual practitioners.

an3.155:5.5.eng: when your deeds have been auspicious,

an3.155:6.3.eng: May you and all your relatives

an3.156:1.3.pli: Āgāḷhā paṭipadā, nijjhāmā paṭipadā, majjhimā paṭipadā.
an3.156:1.3.eng: The addicted practice, the scorching practice, and the middle practice.

an3.156:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco evaṃvādī hoti evaṃdiṭṭhi:
an3.156:1.5.eng: It’s when someone has this doctrine and view:

an3.156:1.7.eng: so they throw themselves into sensual pleasures.

an3.156:1.8.eng: This is called the addicted practice.

an3.156:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco acelako hoti muttācāro, hatthāpalekhano, naehibhadantiko, natiṭṭhabhadantiko, nābhihaṭaṃ na uddissakataṃ na nimantanaṃ sādiyati.
an3.156:2.2.eng: It’s when someone goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on their behalf, or an invitation for a meal.

an3.156:2.3.pli: So na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti, na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhāti na eḷakamantaraṃ na daṇḍamantaraṃ na musalamantaraṃ na dvinnaṃ bhuñjamānānaṃ na gabbhiniyā na pāyamānāya na purisantaragatāya na saṅkittīsu na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti na yattha makkhikā saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī na macchaṃ na maṃsaṃ na suraṃ na merayaṃ, na thusodakaṃ pivati.
an3.156:2.3.eng: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a hound waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.

an3.156:2.4.pli: So ekāgāriko vā hoti ekālopiko, dvāgāriko vā hoti dvālopiko … sattāgāriko vā hoti sattālopiko;
an3.156:2.4.eng: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.

an3.156:2.5.pli: ekissāpi dattiyā yāpeti, dvīhipi dattīhi yāpeti … sattahipi dattīhi yāpeti;
an3.156:2.5.eng: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.

an3.156:2.6.pli: ekāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti, dvāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti … sattāhikampi āhāraṃ āhāreti—iti evarūpaṃ addhamāsikampi pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
an3.156:2.6.eng: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live pursuing the practice of eating food at set intervals.

an3.156:3.1.pli: So sākabhakkhopi hoti, sāmākabhakkhopi hoti, nīvārabhakkhopi hoti, daddulabhakkhopi hoti, haṭabhakkhopi hoti, kaṇabhakkhopi hoti, ācāmabhakkhopi hoti, piññākabhakkhopi hoti, tiṇabhakkhopi hoti, gomayabhakkhopi hoti, vanamūlaphalāhāro yāpeti pavattaphalabhojī.
an3.156:3.1.eng: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.

an3.156:4.1.pli: So sāṇānipi dhāreti, masāṇānipi dhāreti, chavadussānipi dhāreti, paṃsukūlānipi dhāreti, tirīṭānipi dhāreti, ajinampi dhāreti, ajinakkhipampi dhāreti, kusacīrampi dhāreti, vākacīrampi dhāreti, phalakacīrampi dhāreti, kesakambalampi dhāreti, vāḷakambalampi dhāreti, ulūkapakkhikampi dhāreti,
an3.156:4.1.eng: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.

an3.156:4.2.eng: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.

an3.156:4.3.eng: They constantly stand, turning down seats.

an3.156:4.4.eng: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.

an3.156:4.5.eng: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.

an3.156:4.6.eng: They’re devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including at dusk.

an3.156:4.7.pli: iti evarūpaṃ anekavihitaṃ kāyassa ātāpanaparitāpanānuyogamanuyutto viharati.
an3.156:4.7.eng: And so they live pursuing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.

an3.156:4.8.eng: This is called the scorching practice.

an3.156:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
an3.156:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

an3.156:5.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

an3.156:5.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind …

an3.156:5.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
an3.156:5.5.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

an3.156:5.6.eng: This is called the middle practice.

an3.157:1.3.pli: Āgāḷhā paṭipadā, nijjhāmā paṭipadā, majjhimā paṭipadā.
an3.157:1.3.eng: The addicted practice, the scorching practice, the middle practice.

an3.157:1.5.eng: This is called the addicted practice.

an3.157:2.1.eng: And what is the scorching practice? …

an3.157:2.2.eng: This is called the scorching practice.

an3.157:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati;
an3.157:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.

an3.157:3.3.pli: uppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati;
an3.157:3.3.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up.

an3.157:3.4.pli: anuppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ uppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati;
an3.157:3.4.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.

an3.157:3.5.pli: uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati ….
an3.157:3.5.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development. …

an3.158:1.1.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort.

an3.158:1.2.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort.

an3.158:1.3.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort.

an3.158:1.4.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort. …

an3.159:1.1.eng: They develop the faculty of faith …

an3.160:1.1.eng: They develop the power of faith …

an3.161:1.1.eng: They develop the awakening factor of mindfulness …

an3.162:1.9.eng: This is called the middle practice.

an3.16:1.1.pli: “Tīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu apaṇṇakapaṭipadaṃ paṭipanno hoti, yoni cassa āraddhā hoti āsavānaṃ khayāya.
an3.16:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when a mendicant has three things their practice is unfailing, and they have laid the groundwork for ending the defilements.

an3.16:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti, bhojane mattaññū hoti, jāgariyaṃ anuyutto hoti.
an3.16:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant guards the sense doors, eats in moderation, and is dedicated to wakefulness.

an3.16:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti?
an3.16:2.1.eng: And how does a mendicant guard the sense doors?

an3.16:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
an3.16:2.2.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

an3.16:2.3.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṃ, cakkhundriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
an3.16:2.3.eng: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.

an3.16:2.4.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

an3.16:2.5.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

an3.16:2.6.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

an3.16:2.7.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

an3.16:2.8.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
an3.16:2.8.eng: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.

an3.16:2.9.pli: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṃ manindriyaṃ asaṃvutaṃ viharantaṃ abhijjhādomanassā pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṃ tassa saṃvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṃ, manindriye saṃvaraṃ āpajjati.
an3.16:2.9.eng: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.

an3.16:2.10.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
an3.16:2.10.eng: That’s how a mendicant guards the sense doors.

an3.16:3.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bhojane mattaññū hoti?
an3.16:3.1.eng: And how does a mendicant eat in moderation?

an3.16:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paṭisaṅkhā yoniso āhāraṃ āhāreti:
an3.16:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant reflects rationally on the food that they eat:

an3.16:3.3.pli: ‘neva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya na vibhūsanāya, yāvadeva imassa kāyassa ṭhitiyā yāpanāya vihiṃsūparatiyā brahmacariyānuggahāya, iti purāṇañca vedanaṃ paṭihaṅkhāmi, navañca vedanaṃ na uppādessāmi, yātrā ca me bhavissati anavajjatā ca phāsuvihāro cā’ti.
an3.16:3.3.eng: ‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will have the means to keep going, blamelessness, and a comfortable abiding.’

an3.16:3.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bhojane mattaññū hoti.
an3.16:3.4.eng: That’s how a mendicant eats in moderation.

an3.16:4.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu jāgariyaṃ anuyutto hoti?
an3.16:4.1.eng: And how is a mendicant dedicated to wakefulness?

an3.16:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu divasaṃ caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṃ parisodheti, rattiyā paṭhamaṃ yāmaṃ caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṃ parisodheti, rattiyā majjhimaṃ yāmaṃ dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ kappeti pāde pādaṃ accādhāya sato sampajāno uṭṭhānasaññaṃ manasi karitvā, rattiyā pacchimaṃ yāmaṃ paccuṭṭhāya caṅkamena nisajjāya āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṃ parisodheti.
an3.16:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant practices walking and sitting meditation by day, purifying their mind from obstacles. In the first watch of the night, they continue to practice walking and sitting meditation. In the middle watch, they lie down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up. In the last watch, they get up and continue to practice walking and sitting meditation, purifying their mind from obstacles.

an3.16:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu jāgariyaṃ anuyutto hoti.
an3.16:4.3.eng: This is how a mendicant is dedicated to wakefulness.

an3.16:4.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu apaṇṇakapaṭipadaṃ paṭipanno hoti, yoni cassa āraddhā hoti āsavānaṃ khayāyā”ti.
an3.16:4.4.eng: When a mendicant possesses these three things their practice is unfailing, and they have laid the groundwork for ending the defilements.”

an3.163:0.2.eng: The Chapter on Ways of Performing Deeds

an3.163:1.1.pli: “Tīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an3.163:1.1.eng: “Someone with three qualities is cast down to hell.

an3.163:1.3.pli: Attanā ca pāṇātipātī hoti, parañca pāṇātipāte samādapeti, pāṇātipāte ca samanuñño hoti.
an3.163:1.3.eng: They themselves kill living creatures. They encourage others to kill living creatures. And they approve of killing living creatures.

an3.163:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an3.163:1.4.eng: Someone with these three qualities is cast down to hell.

an3.164:1.1.pli: Tīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge.
an3.164:1.1.eng: Someone with three qualities is raised up to heaven.

an3.164:1.3.pli: Attanā ca pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, parañca pāṇātipātā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, pāṇātipātā veramaṇiyā ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.164:1.3.eng: They don’t themselves kill living creatures. They encourage others to not kill living creatures. And they approve of not killing living creatures. …

an3.165:1.1.pli: Attanā ca adinnādāyī hoti, parañca adinnādāne samādapeti, adinnādāne ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.165:1.1.eng: They themselves steal. They encourage others to steal. And they approve of stealing. …

an3.166:1.1.pli: Attanā ca adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, parañca adinnādānā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, adinnādānā veramaṇiyā ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.166:1.1.eng: They don’t themselves steal. They encourage others to not steal. And they approve of not stealing. …

an3.167:1.1.pli: Attanā ca kāmesumicchācārī hoti, parañca kāmesumicchācāre samādapeti, kāmesumicchācāre ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.167:1.1.eng: They themselves commit sexual misconduct. They encourage others to commit sexual misconduct. And they approve of committing sexual misconduct. …

an3.168:1.1.pli: Attanā ca kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, parañca kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇiyā ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.168:1.1.eng: They don’t themselves commit sexual misconduct. They encourage others to not commit sexual misconduct. And they approve of not committing sexual misconduct. …

an3.169:1.1.pli: Attanā ca musāvādī hoti, parañca musāvāde samādapeti, musāvāde ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.169:1.1.eng: They themselves lie. They encourage others to lie. And they approve of lying. …

an3.170:1.1.pli: Attanā ca musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, parañca musāvādā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, musāvādā veramaṇiyā ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.170:1.1.eng: They don’t themselves lie. They encourage others to not lie. And they approve of not lying. …

an3.171:1.1.pli: Attanā ca pisuṇavāco hoti, parañca pisuṇāya vācāya samādapeti, pisuṇāya vācāya ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.171:1.1.eng: They themselves speak divisively. They encourage others to speak divisively. And they approve of speaking divisively. …

an3.172:1.1.pli: Attanā ca pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, parañca pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇiyā samādapeti, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇiyā ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.172:1.1.eng: They don’t themselves speak divisively. They encourage others to not speak divisively. And they approve of not speaking divisively. …

an3.173:1.1.pli: Attanā ca pharusavāco hoti, parañca pharusāya vācāya samādapeti, pharusāya vācāya ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.173:1.1.eng: They themselves speak harshly. They encourage others to speak harshly. And they approve of speaking harshly. …

an3.174:1.1.pli: Attanā ca pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, parañca pharusāya vācāya veramaṇiyā samādapeti, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇiyā ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.174:1.1.eng: They don’t themselves speak harshly. They encourage others to not speak harshly. And they approve of not speaking harshly. …

an3.175:1.1.pli: Attanā ca samphappalāpī hoti, parañca samphappalāpe samādapeti, samphappalāpe ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.175:1.1.eng: They themselves talk nonsense. They encourage others to talk nonsense. And they approve of talking nonsense. …

an3.176:1.1.pli: Attanā ca samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti, parañca samphappalāpā veramaṇiyā samādapeti, samphappalāpā veramaṇiyā ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.176:1.1.eng: They don’t themselves talk nonsense. They encourage others to not talk nonsense. And they approve of not talking nonsense. …

an3.177:1.1.pli: Attanā ca abhijjhālu hoti, parañca abhijjhāya samādapeti, abhijjhāya ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.177:1.1.eng: They themselves are covetous. They encourage others to be covetous. And they approve of covetousness. …

an3.178:1.1.pli: Attanā ca anabhijjhālu hoti, parañca anabhijjhāya samādapeti, anabhijjhāya ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.178:1.1.eng: They themselves are content. They encourage others to be contented. And they approve of being contented. …

an3.179:1.1.pli: Attanā ca byāpannacitto hoti, parañca byāpāde samādapeti, byāpāde ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.179:1.1.eng: They themselves have ill will. They encourage others to have ill will. And they approve of having ill will. …

an3.180:1.1.pli: Attanā ca abyāpannacitto hoti, parañca abyāpāde samādapeti, abyāpāde ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.180:1.1.eng: They themselves are kind-hearted. They encourage others to be kind-hearted. And they approve of kind-heartedness. …

an3.181:1.1.pli: Attanā ca micchādiṭṭhiko hoti, parañca micchādiṭṭhiyā samādapeti, micchādiṭṭhiyā ca samanuñño hoti …pe….
an3.181:1.1.eng: They themselves have wrong view. They encourage others to have wrong view. And they approve of wrong view. …

an3.182:1.1.pli: Attanā ca sammādiṭṭhiko hoti, parañca sammādiṭṭhiyā samādapeti, sammādiṭṭhiyā ca samanuñño hoti.
an3.182:1.1.eng: They themselves have right view. They encourage others to have right view. And they approve of right view.

an3.182:1.2.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge”ti.
an3.182:1.2.eng: Someone with these three qualities is raised up to heaven.”

an3.17:1.1.pli: “Tayome, bhikkhave, dhammā attabyābādhāyapi saṃvattanti, parabyābādhāyapi saṃvattanti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi saṃvattanti.
an3.17:1.1.eng: “These three things, mendicants, lead to hurting yourself, hurting others, and hurting both.

an3.17:1.3.eng: Bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.17:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo dhammā attabyābādhāyapi saṃvattanti, parabyābādhāyapi saṃvattanti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi saṃvattanti.
an3.17:1.4.eng: These are three things that lead to hurting yourself, hurting others, and hurting both.

an3.17:2.1.pli: Tayome, bhikkhave, dhammā nevattabyābādhāyapi saṃvattanti, na parabyābādhāyapi saṃvattanti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi saṃvattanti.
an3.17:2.1.eng: These three things, mendicants, don’t lead to hurting yourself, hurting others, or hurting both.

an3.17:2.3.eng: Good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.17:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo dhammā nevattabyābādhāyapi saṃvattanti, na parabyābādhāyapi saṃvattanti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi saṃvattantī”ti.
an3.17:2.4.eng: These are three things that don’t lead to hurting yourself, hurting others, or hurting both.”

an3.18:1.1.pli: “Sace vo, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā evaṃ puccheyyuṃ:
an3.18:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, if wanderers who follow another religion were to ask you:

an3.18:1.2.eng: ‘Reverend, do you lead the spiritual life with the ascetic Gotama so that you can be reborn in the realm of the gods?’

an3.18:1.3.pli: Nanu tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṃ puṭṭhā aṭṭīyeyyātha harāyeyyātha jiguccheyyāthā”ti?
an3.18:1.3.eng: Being questioned like this, wouldn’t you be horrified, repelled, and disgusted?”

an3.18:1.5.pli: “Iti kira tumhe, bhikkhave, dibbena āyunā aṭṭīyatha harāyatha jigucchatha, dibbena vaṇṇena dibbena sukhena dibbena yasena dibbenādhipateyyena aṭṭīyatha harāyatha jigucchatha;
an3.18:1.5.eng: “So it seems that you are horrified, repelled, and disgusted by heavenly lifespan, beauty, happiness, glory, and sovereignty.

an3.18:1.6.pli: pageva kho pana, bhikkhave, tumhehi kāyaduccaritena aṭṭīyitabbaṃ harāyitabbaṃ jigucchitabbaṃ, vacīduccaritena … manoduccaritena aṭṭīyitabbaṃ harāyitabbaṃ jigucchitabban”ti.
an3.18:1.6.eng: How much more then should you be horrified, embarrassed, and disgusted by bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.”

an3.183-352:0.2.eng: The Chapter on Abbreviated Texts Beginning with Greed

an3.183-352:1.1.eng: “For insight into greed, three things should be developed.

an3.183-352:1.3.pli: Suññato samādhi, animitto samādhi, appaṇihito samādhi—
an3.183-352:1.3.eng: Emptiness immersion; signless immersion; and undirected immersion.

an3.183-352:1.4.pli: rāgassa, bhikkhave, abhiññāya ime tayo dhammā bhāvetabbā. (…)
an3.183-352:1.4.eng: For insight into greed, these three things should be developed.

an3.183-352:2.1.eng: For the complete understanding of greed …

an3.183-352:3.26.eng: For the letting go of negligence, these three things should be developed.”

an3.183-352:4.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

an3.183-352:4.2.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
an3.183-352:4.2.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

an3.183-352:8.6.eng: The Book of the Threes is finished.
